repnme.cdata!:
Early education for poor and indigenous
            communities of Nicaragua

abstracts.cdata!:
In 1999, 23 percent of the Nicaraguan
            population age 10 and older was illiterate; in poor rural
            areas, the rate was actually 51 percent. International
            Development Association (IDA) started supporting the
            government's program in 1995 through the first basic
            education project (APRENDE). The project contributed to an
            increase in the enrollment coverage of pre-schools and
            primary schools, particularly in targeted poor and
            indigenous communities. New IDA-supported education project
            (PASEN) was approved in September 2004, supporting the
            strengthening of the education system and including certain
            key activities (notably preschool education, evaluation, and
            management information system) supported under APRENDE.

docna.cdata!:
Early education for poor and indigenous
            communities of Nicaragua

Early education for poor and

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Basic Education Project and
            Supplemental Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts are only modest. Lessons drawn from the project,
            above all reinforce the notion that collaborative efforts
            with communities, are conducive to faster implementation,
            and quality results. In addition, the close collaboration
            between the Bank, and Borrower facilitated the procurement
            implementation schedule for a timely delivery of textbooks,
            and educational materials. Nonetheless, standard procurement
            practices for emergency operations - such is the case of the
            Supplemental Credit following Hurricane Mitch - could be
            redefined, to streamline emergency procurement, and avoid
            unnecessary delays. However, the staff continuity within the
            Project Implementation Unit proved valuable, and should be
            emphasized that even through several political changes, and
            two elected new governments, this continuity assured the
            Government's ability to achieve project objectives.
